I'm really not sure what point you are making here. Stocks that have not passed into the individual's hands are not allowed to be hedged, the unvested stock, which is the part of compensation subject to regulation, but once the employee owns it outright they are entitled to hold the stock, sell the stock, buy puts or sell calls just like any other shareholder!

Shareholders who do not like volatility have the choice of selling their shares or trading options, why on earth should employees not have the right to do likewise given that because of the new restrictions on vesting of shares they are likely to be much much less diversified than almost any other class of investor.

The rules should provide for a mandatory minimum holding period (3 years?) for performance options during which time hedging should be prohibited. After the minimum holding period, the shares could be sold, held and hedged. "Aligning the interests of employees with the firm" is over-rated as a motivator, in my opinion.

comments.commentBody: Does anyone really below that the Dodd Frank bill was written by Dodd and Frank? Nope. The bill was written by industry lobbyists.

Buried in your article is the fact that Goldman employees are not, in fact, permitted to hedge restricted stock -- that is, stock that they're not yet allowed to sell. These restricted shares are the very ownership stake that is designed to tie employees to the firm's fortunes.

Eventually, of course, after some number of years, the employees get to own the shares outright, and sell them if they wish. (If they could never be sold, what would be the point of owning them and working to build up their value?) Would requiring them to sell those shares, rather than hedging them, make these employees any more exposed to Goldman's fortunes? The actions of these partners and other employees seem like a legitimate way to remain invested in Goldman (or another employer) while limiting their worst-case risk.

The Times seems intent on offering speculation about the motivations of anyone who prospers on Wall Street, while glossing over important distinctions with a veneer of know-nothingism. It may make good copy to say that all derivatives are bad, they're never applied for benign reasons, and all Wall Streeters are crooks who are constantly gaming the system. But it's a poor substitute for good reporting.
